Elliotte,

My early experiences writing frameworks were in Smalltalk where =
the audience for the framework was no larger than the team. In Smalltalk, a=
ll data is protected and all methods are public. This caused very few probl=
ems in practice and gave framework users a lot of flexibility. My urge to m=
ake methods protected comes from my experience that good coding practice (C=
omposed Method, for instance) creates many methods which would make excelle=
nt hooks, but that when I wrote the framework I wasn't very good at guessin=
g which methods would be useful hooks and which were just good factoring. I=
n a framework used "among friends", where you can refactor all the client c=
ode, protected data/public methods is a reasonable practice.

However, as E=
rich is at pains to explain to me frequently, that is not the context in wh=
ich we are writing JUnit. We need to balance the need for flexibility of ex=
tension with the need for flexibility of design evolution. Revealing all th=
e details of our implementation means we can't change anything. And so we a=
re left, as you said, revealing only as much as we are certain will be usef=
ul.

This leaves me unsettled. I know that my frameworks aren't as useful a=
s they could be, but I also know that I would regret opening them up comple=
tely. I don't see how to strike a better balance than we strike with JUnit,=
 though, so I'll live with it.

Sincerely yours,

Kent Beck
Three Rivers In=
stitute
